capital management but this michigan survey tell you that the consumer might be downshifting a little bite in term of their confidence and their spend this could be an indication of that  consumer spend account for 66% of us economic activity and be view as a gauge of the health of the economy which be why the michigan data be closely observe however on friday it be overshadow by the core ppi core figure which surge 27% during the past 12 months the biggest year-on-year gain in nine years the concern be that traders might interpret this big jump in the core ppi as an impetus for the feed to be more aggressive than a measure move in move rat say paul cherney chief market analyst at standard & poor but ian shepherdson chief us economist at high frequency economics say the ppi report be jump in january but shepherdson say it be a good bet these increase won't stick

how political squabble snowball  it become commonplace to argue that blair and brown be like squabble school kid and that they (and their supporters) need to grow up and stop bicker  but this analysis in fact get it wrong it not just children who fight - adults do too and there be solid reason why even a trivial argument between mature protagonists can be hard to stop once its get go the key feature of an endless feud be that everyone can agree they'd be better off if it end - but everyone want to have the last word  each participant genuinely want the row to stop but think it worth prolong the argument just a tiny bite to ensure their view be hear their successive attempt to end the argument with their last word ensure the argument go on and on and on (in the case of mr blair and mr brown successive book be publish ensure the issue never die) now this isn't because the participants be stupid - it actually each individual behave entirely rationally give the incentives face them indeed there even a piece of economic theory that explain all this nothing as obscure as post-neo-classical endogenous growth theory which the chancellor himself once quote - but a ubiquitous piece of game theory which all respectable policy wonks be familiar with  it often refer to as the prisoner dilemma base on a parable much tell in economics degree course about a sheriff and two prisoners the story go that two prisoners be jointly charge with a heinous crime and be lock up in separate cells but the sheriff desperately need a confession from at least one of them to provide enough evidence to convict them of the crime without a confession the prisoners will get a minimal sentence on some trump up charge  clearly the prisoners' best strategy be to keep their mouth shut and take the short sentence but the clever sheriff have an idea to induce them to talk he tell each prisoner separately that if they confess - and they be the only one to confess - they'll be let off their crime and he tell them that if they don't confess - and they be the only one not to confess - they'll get life now if you be prisoner confront with this choice your best bet be to confess if your partner doesn't confess you'll get off completely and if your partner do confess you'd better confess to ensure you don't get life the result be of course both prisoners confess so the sheriff do not have to let either one off both prisoners' individual logic be to behave that way even though both would have be better if they have somehow agree to shut up don't worry if you don't entirely follow it - you can to look it up on google where there be 283000 entries on it  the prisoners' dilemma and all its ramifications have truly capture economists in the last couple of decades it be a parable use to describe any situation where there be an obvious sensible choice to be take collectively but where the only rational choice individually be to behave selfishly  a cold war arm race for example - a classic case where both russia and america would be better off with just a few arm rather than a lot of arm but as long as each want just a few more arm than the other an arm race ensue with the result that the individually logical decision to buy more arm result in arm level that be too high what economics tell us be that once you're in a prisoners' dilemma - unless you be repeat the experience many time over - it hard to escape the perverse logic of it it no good just exhort people to stop buy arm or to stop argue when all their incentives encourage them to carry on somehow the incentives have to change  in the case of the labour party if you believe the rift between blair and brown camp be as bad as the report suggest solomon wisdom need to be deploy to solve the problem every parent know there be ingenious solutions to arguments solutions which affect the incentives of the participants an example be the famous rule that one divide the other choose as a way of allocate a piece of cake to be slice up between greedy children in the case of an apparently endless argument if you want it to come to an end you have to ensure the person who have the last word be one who lose rather than the one who win the row the cost of prolong the row by even one more brief or one more book for that matter have to exceed the benefit of have the last word and get your point in if the rest of the party can enforce that they'll have the protagonists retreat pretty quickly

too much critics argue - into enforcement  since then the russian stock market have more than treble in value a rise the author attribute at least in part to the newly tough approach the report highlight the case of sibneft a russian oil company that come close to merge with yukos last year after mr putin come to power the company overall effective tax rate rise from 26% to 104% and sibneft be the target of a series of aggressive raid by fiscal police but shareholders benefit hugely sibneft start to pay dividends - $53m in 2000 and almost $1bn in 2001 - and close down the network of opaque subsidiaries it have previously use for siphon off unofficial fund accord to the author although a variety of change be sweep through russian industry at the time the increase in tax enforcement be the only likely explanation for the change of fortunes at sibneft and many of its peer  do this analysis make sense in part certainly for all its fault corporate russia have become far more orderly and law-abiding since 2000 company have rush to list their share on international stock exchange - something unthinkable in the wilder days of the 1990s - and most large firm now produce their account to international standards foreign direct investment long negligible be start to flow in serious amount - $7bn in 2003 - and stock market return have be among the healthiest in europe but the authors' model do not quite cover all the complexities for a start the model assume that the various party have clearly-defined motivation company want to maximise profit governments want to maximise tax revenue in fact the alarmingly close connections between big business and government in russia - connections often grease by bribery - blur the apparently antagonistic relationship company can for example persuade officials to overlook non-payment of tax  and the authors' definition of tax enforcement seem unrealistically western genuine disinterested tax collection might well work wonder in russia the problem with recent examples have be the erratic and unpredictable way laws be enforce the case against yukos for example have move in fit and start with little clarity from the government about its intentions and little faith from investors that the letter of the law would be follow as far as most commentators be concern the state be pursue yukos out of a political vendetta rather than simply to enforce fiscal rectitude since yukos' founder mikhail khodorkovsky be arrest a year ago the russian market have drop by 10% -
